IT WAS ROSS'S CONTENTION THAT SUCH A SHARING ARRANGEMENT DID NOT ADEQUATELY TAKE INTO ACCOUNT ALL OF THE FACTS SUPPORTING ROSS'S PERSONAL INVOLVEMENT IN THIS ARBITRATION, AND THEREFORE, ROSS REQUESTED THAT HE BE PERMITTED TO PERSONALLY SATISFY THE ENTIRE JUDGEMENT IF IT WAS BELIEVED BY THE FIRM THAT ROSS WAS IN ANY WAY CULPABLE. CRITICAL TO ROSS'S OFFER WAS HIS UNQUESTIONABLE BELIEF THAT HE PERSONALLY HAD NOTHING TO WARRANT ANY JUDGEMENT AGAINST BLAIR AND HIMSELF, AND ROSS THEREFORE DID NOT BELIEVE IT WAS APPROPRIATE THAT BLAIR SHOULD SHARE FINANCIALLY TO ANY EXTENT IF THE FIRM BELIEVED THAT ROSS ACTED IMPROPERLY. AFTER DELIBERATION, BLAIR NEVERTHELESS ELECTED TO GO WITH ITS ORIGINAL PROPOSAL OF EQUAL SHARING, BECAUSE IT WAS AGREED THAT SUCH AN ARRANGEMENT FOR SHARING OF THE LIABILITY WAS THE MOST APPROPRIATE SOLUTION TO THIS MATTER.
